<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_run:
```c
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_run:
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments selected are the places where a pointer to the thread id array is accepted/used only for reading and therefore merit investigation for const-qualification. Other pointers in the code were not included because they are either written to or forwarded to thread entry points and thus cannot trivially be made const: - metal_run_noblock's tids buffer is populated via pthread_create (tid_p[i] is written), so it must be a non-const pointer. - The threads_out (int *threads_out) parameter is written to and therefore must be non-const. - The arg parameter passed to threads is forwarded to the thread function; the thread entry-point may expect to modify that data, so it is not safe to assume it can be const without changing the thread-function API. - The casts from void * to pthread_t * in metal_run_noblock are required because the API uses void *; those conversions involve storing into the array and are not candidates for const. Therefore only the metal_finish_threads definitions and its call site (which currently pass a non-const void *) are flagged as suspicious for possible conversion to accept a const-qualified pointer (e.g., const void * or const pthread_t *), since metal_finish_threads only reads the array.
